text.tspan: downloaded, so they can be added
Also, all GPG MIME parts are hidden;
they are not shown as attachments,
Since messages that are either signed or encrypted are generally done so by
the sender, and since the sender already features prominently in the UI, the
signed/encrypted status should be displayed next to the sender. This can be
done with variations of the existing stock symbolic security icons.
For senders with known good keys, but who did not sign or encrypt the
For senders with known good keys who signed (but not encrypted) the
For senders with known good keys who encrypted (and maybe signed) the
For senders with invalid, revoked, expired, or otherwise problematic keys:
For senders without any known keys (i.e. likely most senders), or for
accounts where encryption is not enabled but a signed/encrypted message
The status icon should be part of the sender's address label, so that when
the user clicks either, the contact popover is shown.
The popover should include an item with the same status icon so as to
reinforce the meaning of the icon, and some short text describing the
status. Clicking the item can show a dialog with more detailed information
about the verification/encryption, the keys involved and their trust leves,
etc. TBD: What will this dialog look like?
This message cannot be displayed since the sender
has encrypted it and a key to decrypt it was not found.
If a message is received encrypted but no suitable key found to decrypt it,
then a message to that effect to should be displayed. A button can be
included to perform a search in the background, which would ideally
launch Seahorse or another existing app to perform the search. If the app
finds and adds the key, Geary should notice and decrypt the message.
A variant of this would also be shown for senders with invalid/revoked/
expired/etc keys with the button invoking an external program to update
the key, and a similar UI can be presented when encryption is not enabled
for an account, in which case the button launches an app to set it up.
TBD: have to check how calling out to an external app would work with
These two aren't standard icons, just
hacks put together for this design.
So all five might need to be
included in Geary's source to ensure
a consistent set until we can get the
two missing icons added to the
The name displayed by this label
should come from the key used to
At startup, Geary should asynchronously load the list of keys with ultimate
trust via GPGME, and for each account if one of its sender email addresses
matches a key with ultimate trust then enable encryption for that account.
No preferences are required here they are already specified by the
account's sender email addresses and GPG keys.
If no such keys match for an account, then the UX should mostly remain as
it is at the moment, unless a signed or encrypted message is received.
If possible, Geary should asynchronously monitor the users's GPG keys and
if a matching key with ultimate trust is created (or deleted) then the
account's status should be updated to match.
